importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky earned international acclaim as the under-12 World Youth Chess Champion in November 2007, establishing himself as a top young talent.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.
The New York Times hired Naroditsky as a chess columnist in 2022, marking a major milestone in his media and educational influence.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: From 2007 to 2019, Naroditsky developed from a young chess prodigy to a prominent educator and media figure, shaping the modern accessibility of chess through digital platforms.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at age 29.
He was born and raised in the San Francisco Bay Area and began playing chess at age 6.
Naroditsky earned the title of grandmaster before high school graduation and won multiple grade-level national championships.
He became the youngest player to win the California K-12 Championship in fifth grade (2007).
In 2007, he won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship, gaining international recognition.
He earned a bachelor’s degree in history from Stanford University in 2019.
He authored a chess manual at age 14 and became a regular contributor to Chess Life magazine and the New York Times.
He built a massive online presence with nearly 500,000 YouTube subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers, livestreaming games and teaching accessible chess strategies.
The Charlotte Chess Center, where he served as head coach, announced his death and described him as a 'cherished member of the chess community'.
The International Chess Federation and Saint Louis Chess Club praised him as a talented player, commentator, and educator.
A moment of silence was observed at the 2025 US Chess Championship in St. Louis in his honor.
Naroditsky’s family has requested privacy following his death.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster born in the San Francisco Bay Area, died at the age of 29. He earned international acclaim at age 12 as the under-12 World Youth Chess Champion and became a grandmaster before high school. After attending Stanford University and earning a history degree in 2019, he gained prominence as a chess educator and media figure, publishing chess manuals and writing for outlets like the New York Times. His massive online following—nearly half a million on YouTube and over 340,000 on Twitch—made him a key figure in popularizing chess through accessible, engaging livestreams. Institutions including the Charlotte Chess Center, the International Chess Federation, and the Saint Louis Chess Club publicly mourned his passing, noting his impact as a player, commentator, and educator. A moment of silence was observed at the 2025 US Chess Championship in St. Louis in his honor, and his family has requested privacy.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
